alert.note: Alert for Admiralty Island; Annette Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Juneau; City and Borough of Sitka; City and Borough of Wrangell; City and Borough of Yakutat; City of Hyder; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Petersburg Borough; Prince of Wales Island; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 05 at 2:07PM AKST by NWS Juneau
info.description: ...WIDESPREAD SNOW FOR THE PANHANDLE LATE SUNDAY INTO MONDAY... A weakening front is expected to move into the panhandle beginning late Sunday and into Monday. Due to cold, stable air in place, an overrunning event for the inner channels looks to bring modest snow accumulation. The strength of the frontal band has been trending down, lowering overall moisture coming into the panhandle slightly. While there appears to be less moisture, colder air looks to stick around longer, which will keep fluffier snow falling for longer. Overall, with the moisture currently expected, guidance has indicated 90% chance that at least 2 inches of snow over 24 hours will occur in areas from Icy Strait down to the southern panhandle. Icy Strait continues to be the bulls eye for higher totals. While less likely, Icy Strait and Juneau have a 20% likelihood of snow totals above 6 inches in 24 hours. Therefore, storm totals look to range between 2-6 inches over 24 hours in the Icy Strait corridor. Areas from Angoon and south look to between 2-4 inches. Ketchikan in particular is now expected to hold onto enough cold air for up to 4 inches to fall. Finally, Yakutat is expected to hold colder air for longer, leading to 2-5 inches of snow before transitioning to rain Sunday evening. Check back for updates on this evolving weather system as we continue to evaluate the atmospheric conditions that could lead to winter weather impacts.
